Award.AwardTitle: Complexity to Clarity: Nonparametric Procedures that Exploit Structured Data and Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern research in the physical sciences involves the use of non-standard aggregate data objects (for example, images, spectra, or hurricane tracks), which are not directly amenable to traditional statistical methods. Naturally, the physical processes that generated these observed data are also often very complicated. Typically the only meaningful "model" is in the form of a high-resolution theoretical or simulation model. For example in cosmology, scientists regularly use large hydrodynamic simulations to understand how the universe formed and evolved. The goal of this project is to develop a new means of combining careful statistical modeling of scientific phenomena with scalable procedures that fully exploit the richness of large collections of complex data without reducing the data to a set of features or templates.

Building on ideas from harmonic analysis and spectral methods, this project is to develop flexible and adaptive nonparametric methods for high-dimensional inference that exploit sparse (and potentially nonlinear) structure in complex data. These methods derive Fourier-like bases that adapt to the intrinsic geometry (e.g., submanifold structure) of the underlying data distribution, and use the empirical basis functions to estimate functions on high-dimensional aggregate objects. The methods go beyond point-estimates in prediction to nonparametric estimation of conditional densities, density ratios and likelihoods of complex, high-dimensional data. A key application of these methods is the calibration of complex simulation models: the inference challenge of determining the settings of input values to these models so that their output approximates either real data or the output of a more complex and computationally-intensive simulation code. On a broader scale, this work will make key methodological contributions to building, interpreting, and using probability models for high-dimensional, complexly-structured data in a wide range of scientific applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern research in the physical sciences involves the use of non-standard data objects (e.g., images, spectra, and hurricane tracks) that are not directly amenable to traditional statistical methods. In addition, the physical processes that generate these data can also be very complicated; typically the only meaningful “model” is a high-resolution theoretical or simulation model. For example, in cosmology, scientists regularly use high-fidelity mechanistic simulations to understand how the Universe formed and evolved. Similarly, large simulation models are commonly used in climate and weather forecasting to study how different environmental factors affect our climate and weather system.

This project has developed new means of combining careful statistical modeling of scientific phenomena with scalable procedures that fully exploit the richness of large collections of complex data objects, without first reducing the data to a small set of features or a priori established templates with known properties. Building on ideas from harmonic analysis (a branch of mathematics concerned with the representation of functions or signals as simpler wave forms) and predictive machine learning (AI techniques primarily focused on making accurate predictions as opposed to inferring the relationship between variables), we have developed (i) statistical tools for extracting scientifically meaningful information from complex data of different modalities (arriving from, e.g., different physical probes such as satellites, particle colliders, and telescopes), (ii) flexible methods for quantifying uncertainties in predictions in complex data settings with minimal assumptions on the underlying data distribution, and (iii) computationally efficient techniques for calibrating high-fidelity simulation models, i.e., determining the settings of input values to these models so that their output approximates either real data or the output of a more complex, but computationally-intensive, simulation code.

Intellectual merit: This research differs from most other statistical and machine learning work for high-dimensional data in that the developed methods go beyond predictive tasks (such as regression and classification) to estimating entire distributions and relationships of variables of interest. In addition, the developed methods adapt to nonlinear structure in the underlying data distribution, scale to large datasets, and offer a nonparametric or “distribution-free” means of estimating general functions of interest in statistics, including conditional densities, density ratios, and likelihoods of complex, high-dimensional data and simulation models. This project has produced 14 published and four submitted peer-reviewed publications in statistics, machine learning and physics journals, in addition to publicly available software packages on CRAN and GitHub repositories, and presentations at multiple statistics workshops and astronomy collaboration meetings.


Broader impact: The ideas exchanged and methods developed as part of this project has an impact in a variety of scientific fields through the results of applying our methods to complex data and simulations. These include new scientific discoveries (e.g., in cosmology and environmental science) as well as results that can help inform policy decisions (e.g., related to global climate and hurricane forecasting and disaster management). The research has been the main thesis topic for three statistics Ph.D. students, has provided summer research projects for seven additional Ph.D. students in statistics and astronomy, and has provided data and statistical methods for use in multiple undergraduate research-based classes.
